channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: European Union Adds Hezbollah to Terror List
item.description: An effort led by Britain brought a unanimous decision against the group’s military wing. Sanctions are expected to include asset freezes.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Former Bank Employees Protest in Beijing
item.description: Thousands of the 400,000 workers, who lost their jobs during an overhaul of China’s state-owned banks, turned out to demand compensation.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Romanian Says Her Tale of Burning Art Treasures Was a Lie
item.description: Olga Dogaru said in court that she had made up her story to protect her son, who has admitted stealing seven works of art by Matisse, Picasso and other modern masters.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: “Charing Cross Bridge, London,” by Claude Monet was one of seven works that were stolen in October from the Kunsthal museum in Rotterdam.

item.title: The Lede: How the Royal Birth Will Be Announced
item.description: Royal officials plan to make the birth public with a framed proclamation mounted on a gold-trimmed wooden easel outside Buckingham Palace.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: Czech Ex-Premier Acknowledges Fault in Corruption Scandal
item.description: Petr Necas, 48, was forced to resign last month after the police charged his chief of staff with bribery and abuse of office.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Dubai Pardons Woman at Center of Rape Dispute
item.description: A Norwegian woman at the center of a Dubai rape claim dispute said that officials have dropped her 16-month sentence for having sex outside marriage and she is free to leave the country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: Books, Brioche and Baby Clothes: The Royal Merchandise
item.description: British retailers, hotels and ceramic factories are betting on the arrival of the royal baby to improve the otherwise gloomy economic situation.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA WERDIGIER
item.media:description: Lydia Leith, a British designer, created items to commemorate the birth of the royal baby.

item.title: The Lede: The Five Stages of the Royal Baby Wait
item.description: A dispatch from the royal-baby watch outside the Lindo Wing of St. Mary’s hospital in central London, where journalists have dutifully waited for more than two weeks.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Earthquakes Hit Area of Northwestern China
item.description: The authorities said 75 people had been confirmed dead after a series of powerful quakes shook parts of Gansu Province.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Police searched for victims in collapsed houses after a 6.6 magnitude earthquake hit Minxian county in Gansu province, China, on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 22
item.description: U.S. Vice President Joe Biden arrived in India on Monday for a four-day visit.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: U.S. Vice President Joe Biden, center, with his wife Jill Biden, left, and Tara Gandhi Bhattacharjee, grand daughter of Mahatma Gandhi, at a museum dedicated to Mahatma Gandhi in New Delhi.

item.title: Thathri Journal: Setbacks From Within in Struggle to End Kashmir’s Violence
item.description: The discovery of an unexploded grenade outside the police station in Thathri, Kashmir, had some people fearing that the recent relative quiet in the region might not last.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A road in Indian-controlled Kashmir, where bloody clashes had quieted down. A police officer in Thathri has been accused of being the mastermind of bombing and assassination attempts.

item.title: Report Finds Gradual Fall in Female Genital Cutting in Africa
item.description: An assessment by Unicef describes the ancient practice as “remarkably tenacious,” but finds declines in the procedure in more than half of the countries where it is concentrated.
item.dc:creator: By CELIA W. DUGGER
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senegalese children gather for a Koran reading class given by Imam Moussa Diallo in the village of Hare Saruna, in Southern Senegal. Once Imams explained that cutting is not sanctioned or required by Islam, the practice began to be abandoned.

item.title: Royal Family Says Duchess of Cambridge Is in Labor
item.description: In the early hours on Monday, the duchess, the former Kate Middleton, was admitted to St. Mary’s Hospital in London to prepare for the birth of her first child.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, in February in London.

item.title: Letter from Europe: Germans Play for Time in the Debate on Drones
item.description: With the German public having a deep-seated fear of using armed drones, the Social Democrats could call for a European legal framework to regulate their use. So far, the opposition party has failed to do so.
item.dc:creator: By JUDY DEMPSEY

item.title: The Lede: Wait for Royal Baby Lets a Nation Revel in Nostalgia
item.description: It is hard not to be struck by the frantic enthusiasm the monarchy still seems to inspire in 21st-century Britain.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: The Lede: Whether a Boy or a Girl, Third in Line to the Throne
item.description: For the first time in the history of the British monarchy the issue of the baby’s sex is constitutionally irrelevant, too, at least in terms of succession.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: Thomas Bernhard in New Delhi
item.description: The foundation stone of the 1984 Sikh massacre memorial was laid in Delhi in June. A novelist who survived the pogrom looks back.
item.dc:creator: By JASPREET SINGH

item.title: The Lede: Live Video of Royal Baby Watch in London
item.description: The Lede will have dispatches from reporters in London and news of the reaction online, where professional and amateur royal watchers have been engaged in the Internet’s version of nervous pacing in the hall for more than a week.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Russia Says Assad Is Ready for Peace Talks
item.description: Sergey V. Lavrov, the foreign minister, blames rebels for stalling and asks the United States for help in the negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: U.S. Navy Says Jettisoned Bombs Pose No Threat to Great Barrier Reef
item.description: The United States Navy said that it released four unarmed bombs into the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park during a training exercise to avoid damaging several vessels that had entered the area.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: India Ink: An Afghan Church Grows in Delhi
item.description: Afghan coverts to Christianity find refuge in Delhi.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By NEYAZ FAROOQUEE
item.media:description: A still from a television program that shows Abdul Rahman, right, who converted from Islam to Christianity, holding a translated version of the Bible at a court in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Mar. 23, 2006.

item.title: Wave of Violence Continues in Iraq
item.description: A suicide bomber drove into an army patrol on Monday, killing 13 people in Mosul, and on Sunday night, 29 people were killed in coordinated attacks on two prisons in Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: Women walked past a building in Baghdad that was damaged in one of the bombings that killed dozens over the weekend.

item.title: Across Syria, Violent Day of Attacks and Ambush
item.description: Government forces killed dozens of rebels in an ambush east of Damascus, fighters linked to Al Qaeda battled Kurdish militias and Syria’s military peppered an outdoor market with mortar rounds.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Iraq: 25 Security Forces Dead in Prison Raid
item.description: Officials said a suicide attack against an army patrol in the northern city of Mosul killed nine soldiers and three civilians, and injured 14 others.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Iraq Army Convoy, Killing 25
item.description: A suicide bomber attacked an Iraqi army convoy in the northern city of Mosul early on Monday, killing at least 22 soldiers and three passers-by, police said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
